questions.question: What are metals?
questions.answer: Metals are elements that are generally hard, shiny and good conductors of heat and electricity. They can be beaten into sheets and drawn into wires.

questions.question: What are nonmetals?
questions.answer: Nonmetals are elements that are usually dull, brittle and poor conductors of heat and electricity. They gain electrons during reactions.

questions.question: What are metalloids?
questions.answer: Metalloids are elements showing properties of both metals and nonmetals. Example: silicon and germanium.

questions.question: What is malleability?
questions.answer: Malleability is the property of metals by which they can be beaten into thin sheets without breaking.

questions.question: What is ductility?
questions.answer: Ductility is the property of metals by which they can be drawn into thin wires. Copper is highly ductile.

questions.question: What is sonority?
questions.answer: Sonority is the property by which metals produce ringing sound when struck. Hence metals are used to make bells.

questions.question: Why are metals good conductors?
questions.answer: Metals have free electrons that can move easily. This allows electric current and heat to pass through them.

questions.question: Why are nonmetals poor conductors?
questions.answer: Nonmetals do not have free electrons for easy movement, so they do not conduct electricity well.

questions.question: Why graphite conducts electricity?
questions.answer: Graphite has free electrons between its layers which can move easily, allowing current to pass.

questions.question: Why sodium is very reactive?
questions.answer: Sodium has only one valence electron which it loses easily to achieve stable configuration.

questions.question: Why noble metals are less reactive?
questions.answer: They have stable electronic configuration and do not lose electrons easily, so they do not corrode.

questions.question: What is corrosion?
questions.answer: Corrosion is slow destruction of metals by reaction with air, moisture or chemicals, like rusting of iron.

questions.question: What is rust?
questions.answer: Rust is reddish-brown coating of hydrated iron oxide formed when iron reacts with oxygen and water.

questions.question: Why rusting is harmful?
questions.answer: Rust weakens iron objects and reduces their strength, leading to damage and economic loss.

questions.question: How can corrosion be prevented?
questions.answer: By painting, oiling, galvanization and alloying, we can prevent metal from contacting air and moisture.

questions.question: What is galvanization?
questions.answer: It is coating of iron with zinc to protect it from rusting. Zinc forms protective layer.

questions.question: What is alloying?
questions.answer: Alloying is mixing metal with another metal or nonmetal to improve properties like strength and corrosion resistance.

questions.question: Why alloys are better than pure metals?
questions.answer: Alloys are stronger, harder and more resistant to corrosion than pure metals.

questions.question: What is brass used for?
questions.answer: Brass is used in utensils, musical instruments and fittings due to strength and corrosion resistance.

questions.question: Why stainless steel is rust resistant?
questions.answer: Chromium in stainless steel forms protective oxide layer preventing corrosion.

questions.question: Why iron pillar of Delhi does not rust?
questions.answer: Due to presence of phosphorus and special alloy composition that prevents corrosion.

questions.question: Why copper vessels are tinned?
questions.answer: Tin coating prevents formation of poisonous copper salts with acidic food.

questions.question: Why aluminium does not corrode easily?
questions.answer: It forms thin oxide layer on surface which protects metal from further reaction.

questions.question: Why sodium is stored in kerosene?
questions.answer: To prevent reaction with air and moisture which can cause fire.

questions.question: Why gold is used in jewellery?
questions.answer: Gold is shiny, less reactive and does not corrode, making it long lasting.

questions.question: Why iron is used in construction?
questions.answer: Iron is strong, cheap and available in large quantity for building structures.

questions.question: Why aluminium is used in aeroplanes?
questions.answer: Aluminium is light in weight and strong, reducing total weight of aircraft.

questions.question: Why silver is used in electrical contacts?
questions.answer: Silver is the best conductor of electricity and ensures efficient current flow.

questions.question: Why iron rusts faster in coastal areas?
questions.answer: High moisture and salt in air increase corrosion rate.

questions.question: Why metals are good reflectors of heat?
questions.answer: Free electrons in metals reflect heat energy efficiently.

questions.question: Why nonmetals form acidic oxides?
questions.answer: They react with oxygen to form oxides that dissolve in water forming acids.

questions.question: Why metals form basic oxides?
questions.answer: Metal oxides react with water to form bases or alkalis.

questions.question: Why carbon dioxide is acidic?
questions.answer: It forms carbonic acid when dissolved in water.

questions.question: Why magnesium burns with bright flame?
questions.answer: Magnesium reacts rapidly with oxygen releasing lot of energy and bright light.

questions.question: Why iron reacts slowly with water?
questions.answer: Iron needs heat and moisture to react, so reaction is slow.

questions.question: Why copper does not react with dilute acids?
questions.answer: Copper is less reactive and cannot displace hydrogen from acids.

questions.question: Why metals lose electrons?
questions.answer: To achieve stable electronic configuration similar to noble gases.

questions.question: Why nonmetals gain electrons?
questions.answer: To complete their valence shell and become stable.

questions.question: Why ionic compounds conduct electricity in solution?
questions.answer: Because ions are free to move and carry electric current.

questions.question: Why solid salts do not conduct electricity?
questions.answer: Ions are fixed in lattice and cannot move freely.

questions.question: Why metals are shiny?
questions.answer: Free electrons reflect light, giving metallic lustre.

questions.question: Why nonmetals are dull?
questions.answer: They lack free electrons to reflect light.

questions.question: Why iron is magnetic?
questions.answer: Arrangement of electrons allows magnetic domains to form.

questions.question: Why sulphur is brittle?
questions.answer: Nonmetallic structure breaks easily under pressure.

questions.question: Why zinc protects iron in galvanization?
questions.answer: Zinc reacts first with air and prevents iron from rusting.

questions.question: Why food is stored in aluminium foil?
questions.answer: It prevents moisture and air from spoiling food.

questions.question: Why steel is used in bridges?
questions.answer: Steel is strong and flexible, making structures durable.

questions.question: Why iron tools are painted?
questions.answer: To prevent contact with air and moisture, stopping rust.

questions.question: Why copper wires are coated with plastic?
questions.answer: Plastic prevents electric shock and short circuit.

questions.question: Why nonmetals are used in fertilizers?
questions.answer: Nitrogen and phosphorus are essential nutrients for plants.

questions.question: Why metals are recycled?
questions.answer: To conserve resources and reduce environmental pollution.

questions.question: Why corrosion is economic problem?
questions.answer: It damages structures and machines, increasing maintenance cost.

questions.question: Why gold does not rust?
questions.answer: It does not react with air or moisture easily.

questions.question: Why alloys are used for coins?
questions.answer: They are hard and resist wear and corrosion.

questions.question: Why iron is mixed with carbon to make steel?
questions.answer: Carbon increases hardness and strength of iron.

questions.question: Why magnesium is used in fireworks?
questions.answer: It burns with bright white light producing dazzling effects.

questions.question: Why zinc is used in batteries?
questions.answer: It easily loses electrons and acts as good electrode.

questions.question: Why copper is used in electrical wiring?
questions.answer: It is good conductor and flexible for making wires.

questions.question: Why lead is used in radiation shields?
questions.answer: High density of lead blocks harmful radiation.

questions.question: Why iron rusts faster when scratched?
questions.answer: Protective coating is removed exposing iron to air and moisture.

questions.question: Why metals form positive ions?
questions.answer: They lose electrons and become positively charged.

questions.question: Why nonmetals form negative ions?
questions.answer: They gain electrons and become negatively charged.

questions.question: Why rusting needs water?
questions.answer: Water acts as medium for electrochemical reactions during corrosion.

questions.question: Why aluminium foil is used in packaging?
questions.answer: It is light, flexible and prevents air entry.

questions.question: Why metals expand on heating?
questions.answer: Particles move faster and occupy more space when heated.

questions.question: Why nonmetals do not show sonority?
questions.answer: They are not elastic enough to produce ringing sound.

questions.question: Why silver turns black?
questions.answer: It reacts with hydrogen sulphide forming silver sulphide.

questions.question: Why copper turns green?
questions.answer: Due to formation of copper carbonate on surface.

questions.question: Why iron is more reactive than copper?
questions.answer: Iron loses electrons more easily compared to copper.

questions.question: Why zinc protects iron even when scratched?
questions.answer: Zinc reacts first and sacrifices itself, protecting iron.

questions.question: Why metals are used in making machines?
questions.answer: They are strong and can withstand heavy load and heat.

questions.question: Why nonmetals are used in medicines?
questions.answer: Many nonmetals are essential for body functions.

questions.question: Why silicon is used in electronics?
questions.answer: It is semiconductor and controls current flow.

questions.question: Why oxygen supports combustion?
questions.answer: It reacts with substances and helps burning process.

questions.question: Why nitrogen is less reactive?
questions.answer: Strong triple bond makes nitrogen stable.

questions.question: Why phosphorus is stored in water?
questions.answer: To prevent it from catching fire in air.

questions.question: Why sulphur is used in rubber?
questions.answer: It increases strength and elasticity during vulcanization.

questions.question: Why metals conduct heat quickly?
questions.answer: Free electrons transfer heat energy rapidly.

questions.question: Why nonmetals are not malleable?
questions.answer: They break easily when hammered.

questions.question: Why metals are used in making tools?
questions.answer: They are hard and durable for heavy work.

questions.question: Why alloys resist corrosion?
questions.answer: Different atoms prevent easy oxidation of metal.

questions.question: Why aluminium is used in kitchen?
questions.answer: It conducts heat well and is light weight.

questions.question: Why copper is reddish in colour?
questions.answer: It reflects red light more than other colours.

questions.question: Why iron is essential for body?
questions.answer: It is needed to make haemoglobin for oxygen transport.

questions.question: Why calcium is important mineral?
questions.answer: It helps in forming strong bones and teeth.

questions.question: Why zinc is used for galvanizing?
questions.answer: It forms protective layer and corrodes first.

questions.question: Why metals are shiny after polishing?
questions.answer: Polishing removes oxide layer exposing fresh metal.

questions.question: Why copper is used in cooking vessels?
questions.answer: It conducts heat efficiently and cooks food evenly.

questions.question: Why rust spreads quickly once started?
questions.answer: Rust is porous and allows moisture to reach metal.

questions.question: Why metals form metallic bonds?
questions.answer: Free electrons create strong attraction between metal atoms.

questions.question: Why sodium chloride is ionic compound?
questions.answer: Sodium transfers electron to chlorine forming ions.

questions.question: Why iron is magnetic but copper is not?
questions.answer: Iron has magnetic domains that align easily.

questions.question: Why metals can be welded?
questions.answer: They melt and join easily due to metallic bonding.

questions.question: Why nonmetals form covalent bonds?
questions.answer: They share electrons to complete valence shell.

questions.question: Why steel is stronger than iron?
questions.answer: Carbon atoms prevent sliding of iron layers.

questions.question: Why metals are sonorous?
questions.answer: Elastic nature allows vibration and sound production.

questions.question: Why silver is used in mirrors?
questions.answer: It reflects light very efficiently.

questions.question: Why aluminium is corrosion resistant?
questions.answer: Oxide layer protects surface from further reaction.

questions.question: Why metals are ductile?
questions.answer: Layers of atoms slide without breaking bonds.

questions.question: Give conclusion of Metals and Nonmetals chapter.
questions.answer: Metals and nonmetals have different properties and uses. Understanding them helps in selecting materials for daily life and industry.
